facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 82 of 1957 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Criminal Appeal No. 82 of 1957. Appeal by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from Allahabad High Court judgment dated 12th August 1953 in Criminal Appeal No. 114 of 1951.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated the 12th August, 1953, of the Allahabad High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 114 of 1951 arising out of the judgment

facts.text: Allahabad High Court appeal arose from Additional Sessions Judge Allahabad judgment dated 31st July 1950 in Sessions Trial No. 22 of 1949.

anchor.surface_text: arising out of the judgment and order dated the 31st July, 1950, of the Court of the Additional Sessions Judge at Allahabad in Criminal Sessions Trial No. 22 of 1949.

facts.text: Appellant charged under sections 408 and 477A of the Indian Penal Code.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant bad been charged under ss. 408 and 477A of the Indian Penal Code, and tried by jury of 5.

facts.text: Appellant tried by jury of 5 members.

anchor.surface_text: and tried by jury of 5. The jury returned a unanimous verdict of number guilty.

facts.text: Jury returned unanimous verdict of not guilty.

anchor.surface_text: The jury returned a unanimous verdict of number guilty. The learned Additional Sessions Judge accepted the verdict of the jury and acquitted the accused.

facts.text: Additional Sessions Judge acquitted the accused on July 31, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: setting aside the order of acquittal passed by the learned Additional Sessions Judge at Allahabad, dated July 31, 1950, in Sessions Trial No. 22 of 1949.

facts.text: Government of Uttar Pradesh appealed to High Court.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal by the Government of Uttar Pradesh, the High Court in a judgment companyering about 130 typed pages set aside the order of acquittal

facts.text: Allahabad High Court set aside acquittal and convicted appellant under ss. 408 and 477A IPC on August 12, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: the judgment and order dated August 12, 1953, of a Division Bench of the Allahabad High Court  Desai and Beg JJ.  , setting aside the order of acquittal

facts.text: High Court sentenced appellant to rigorous imprisonment for four years and fine of ten thousand rupees under s. 408 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: and sentenced him to rigorous imprisonment for four years and a fine of ten thousand rupees, in default of payment, further rigorous imprisonment for one year, under s. 408, Indian Penal Code,

facts.text: High Court sentenced appellant to rigorous imprisonment for four years under s. 477A IPC, sentences to run consecutively.

anchor.surface_text: and to rigorous imprisonment for four years under s. 477A, Indian Penal Code, the sentences of imprisonment under the two sections to run companysecutively.

facts.text: Out of fine, seven thousand rupees to be paid to Imperial Bank of India, Allahabad as compensation.

anchor.surface_text: Out of the fine, if realized, seven thousand rupees was directed to be paid to the Imperial Bank of India, Allahabad, as companypensation.

facts.text: High Court refused certificate for appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The prayer for a certificate of fitness for appeal to this Court was refused.

facts.text: Supreme Court granted special leave to appeal on December 15, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant moved this Court and obtained special leave to appeal by order dated December 15, 1953.

facts.text: Appellant committed criminal breach of trust in respect of valuable securities amounting to Rs. 7,410 of Imperial Bank at Allahabad while employed as clerk.

anchor.surface_text: the appellant was charged under the sections aforesaid, for having companymitted criminal breach of trust in respect of valuable securities amounting to Rs. 7,410 odd of the Imperial Bank at Allahabad, while in the employment of the Bank as a clerk,

facts.text: Appellant destroyed, altered, mutilated and falsified accounts and papers during January to July 1946 with intent to defraud.

anchor.surface_text: and had in that capacity, with intent to defraud, destroyed, altered, mutilated and falsified accounts and other papers during January to July, 1946.

facts.text: Case involved large volume of documentary evidence in English.

anchor.surface_text: This case involved a companysideration of a large volume of documentary evidence almost all in English.

facts.text: Prosecution witness No. 26, Mr. Ganguli, Agent of the Bank, examined on 12 days between October and December 1949.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Ganguli, prosecution witness No. 26 -Agent of the Bank-was examined at great length, and be gave his evidence on 12 days between October and December, 1949,

facts.text: High Court found that out of five jurors, three had sufficient knowledge of English, fourth knew very little, fifth had insufficient knowledge.

anchor.surface_text: Out of the five jurors selected by the learned Sessions Judge, three had sufficient knowledge of English, fourth knew very little English and companyld number read the documents produced in the case and the fifth also had number sufficient knowledge of English

facts.text: Jurors Shri Sheik Ashique Ali and Shri Farman Ali lacked sufficient English to decide authorship of documents.

anchor.surface_text: We are satisfied that the two jurors, Shri Sheik Ashique Ali and Shri Farman Ali, were number in a position to decide the question of authorship of the forged documents satisfactorily.

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed the appeal and set aside the convictions and sentences.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal is, accordingly, allowed and the companyvictions and the sentences are set aside.

facts.text: Offence committed about eleven years before 1957.

anchor.surface_text: It is unfortunate that a prosecution which has been pending so long in respect of an offence which is said to have been companymitted about eleven years ago,

anchor.surface_text: A memorandum of appeal is meant to be a succinct statement of the grounds upon which the appellant proposes to support the appeal. It is a notice to the Court that such and such specific grounds are proposed to be urged

holdings.text: The defect in the memorandum of appeal was not such as to render it null and void so as to entitle the High Court to reject it in limine.

anchor.surface_text: In respect of the first contention, it is enough to say that though the memorandum of appeal filed in the High Court was wholly inadequate, the defect was not such as to render it null and void so as to entitle the High Court to reject it in limine.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.419 CrPC requires only written petition with copy of judgment and heads of charge; no provision mandates specifying grounds of fact or law.

holdings.text: There is no provision in the Code which required that the petition of appeal should specify the matters of fact or of law on which the appeal is based.

anchor.surface_text: s. 419 which is the specific provision of the Code of Criminal Procedure, relating to petition of appeal, only requires that it shall be in writing and accompanied by a copy of the judgment or order appealed against,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading of s.419 CrPC; High Court view assumed correct.

holdings.text: Practice of filing memorandum of appeal with bald grounds like 'against weight of evidence' is wasteful and should be discontinued.

anchor.surface_text: A memorandum of appeal is meant to be a succinct statement of the grounds upon which the appellant proposes to support the appeal. It is a notice to the Court that such and such specific grounds are proposed to be urged

holdings.reasoning_summary: Promotes efficient justice; avoids surprise and time waste in overburdened courts.

holdings.text: The trial in the Sessions Court was no trial at all in the eye of law (coram non judice) due to incompetence of jurors lacking sufficient English knowledge to assess documents.

anchor.surface_text: On that finding, it is clear that the appellants contention that it was a trial coram non judice is well-founded. This case is analogous to the case of Ras Behari Lal v. The King Emperor

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court findings confirm two jurors unable to decide document authorship; denies accused essential protection; analogous to Ras Behari Lal v. King Emperor (Privy Council).

holdings.text: Incompetence of jury renders trial a nullity irrespective of unanimous not guilty verdict; prejudice irrelevant as it is mis-trial, not mere irregularity.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows Ras Behari Lal; incompetence denies essential protection under law regardless of outcome.

holdings.text: The instant case was not fit to be tried by an ordinary jury given the complicated nature involving mass of English documents.

anchor.surface_text: We consider that the instant case was not fit to be tried by a jury at least by any ordinary jury. It was a very complicated case in which a mass of documents was produced.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Case required good knowledge of English to judge document authorship; ordinary jurors incompetent.

precedents.citation: Ras Behari Lal v. The King Emperor 1 1933 L.R. 60 I.A. 354, 357

anchor.surface_text: This case is analogous to the case of Ras Behari Lal v. The King Emperor  1 , which went up to the Judicial Committee of the Privy Council, from a judgment of the Patna High Court confirming the conviction and the sentences of the accused persons on a charge of murder and rioting. In that case, the trial was by a jury of 7. The jury by a majority of six to one found the accused guilty.

precedents.case_name: Ras Behari Lal v. The King Emperor
precedents.cited_proposition: Incompetence of even one juror in understanding the proceedings (due to lack of knowledge of English) renders the trial a nullity, denying the accused essential legal protection, resulting in a miscarriage of justice such that conviction and sentence cannot stand.
precedents.cited_holding: They think that the effect of the incompetence of a juror is to deny to the accused an essential part of the protection accorded to him by law and that the result of the trial in the present case was a clear miscarriage of justice. They have no doubt that in those circumstances the conviction and sentence should not be allowed to stand.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal is, accordingly, allowed and the convictions and the sentences are set aside.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal allowed; convictions and sentences set aside
directions: it will be open to the State Government, if it is so advised, to take steps for a retrial, as was directed by the Judicial Committee in the reported case referred to above.
We do not express any opinion on the question whether it is a fit case for a de novo trial by a competent jury or by a Court of Session without a jury, if the present state of the law permits it.
